title: One-on-One Tech Help at Main Library
description: Looking for some basic computer or mobile device guidance? Want to learn how to access audiobooks and eBooks? Stop by at the Main Library for our drop-in hours! Drop-in sessions will be limited to 30-minutes for each patron. We can help you with: accessing library eBooks, audiobooks, and other eResources on your devices e-mail and searching the web smartphone and mobile app questions We are not able to help you with: installing advanced software programs completing online transactions for you computer hardware and technical maintenance To view all available timeslots and dates, use the following link: One-on-One Tech Help schedule. Registration is strongly encouraged but not required. If you have any questions, please contact Gina Josette Rivera by email at gjosette@cambridgema.gov

title: Aging with Mindfulness (Virtual)
description: This program, led by Zeenat Potia, will introduce and utilize mindfulness techniques to help us examine and regulate everyday life changes with a focus on aging. Participants will learn and benefit from the development of a mindfulness practice to enable responding to getting older in a calm, clear and thoughtful manner. Presented in Partnership with Cambridge Insight Meditation Center (CIMC). Rooted in the Theravada Buddhist tradition,CIMC is a welcoming refuge and teaching Center for all who seek inner peace through the liberating practice of Insight Meditation (vipassana). As an urban center, and now as an online community, CIMC is dedicated to the integration of practice into every aspect of community and daily life. Visit the CIMC Website. Registration is required. This is a virtual event. A Zoom link will be sent to all registered participants 1 hour before the event.

description: Learn how to use our Epilog Zing—an industry-standard laser cutting machine. Complete this workshop to earn a badge for the Zing laser cutter. With a badge, you can reserve the Epilog Zing to use on our equipment booking page at designated times. Note: The Epilog Zing laser cutter and Glowforge laser cutter require separate trainings. You must participate in the Glowforge workshop in order to operate our Glowforge Pro laser cutter. You must complete Hive Safety Training before registering for this workshop.

This is not an instructional class, but rather a gathering for individuals who want to play and test their skills against other members of the community. There's no need to register in advance - simply drop by and challenge yourself to improve your mastery of this classic game! If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us at 617-349-4017 or via email: ipachoncaballero@cambridgema.gov or mmcglathery@cambridgema.gov

Free toothbrushes, toothpaste, floss, and local dental care resources will be available for everyone.

title: The First Commander Remembered: Washington’s Legacy in Cambridge (Main/Virtual)
description: To mark the 250th anniversaries of the American Revolution and the founding of the United States, a coalition of local non-profits and government agencies will present Washington in American Memory, a seven-part speaker series. Debunk myths and trace the evolution of the public memory of George Washington in Cambridge, Massachusetts, featuring: J.L. Bell, author of The Road to Concord: How Four Stolen Cannon Ignited the Revolutionary War and proprietor of Boston1775.net Charles Sullivan, co-author of Building Old Cambridge: Architecture and Development and Executive Director of the Cambridge Historical Commission

title: Know Your Rights: Information Session for TPS Recipients (Central Square/Virtual)
description: Join us for a Know Your Rights presentation led by an attorney from De Novo. This session will share important updates for Temporary Protected Status (TPS) recipients, including: How to renew your TPS Work permit and travel information Legal supports and available resources You’ll also have the chance to ask questions and connect with local organizations that can help with ongoing support. This a hybrid event. A Zoom link will be sent to all registered participants 1 hour before the event. We will be providing interpretation in Spanish and Haitian Creole on location during the event. Registration is encouraged but not required. Pizza will be provided! Vin jwenn nou pou yon prezantasyon ak yon avoka imigrasyon De Novo sou Estati Pwoteksyon Tanporè (TPS). Nou pral eksplore sijè tankou: Kijan pou renouvle pèmi Travay TPS ou ak enfòmasyon sou vwayaj Sipò legal ak resous ki disponib Pou wè prezantasyon sa a sou Zoom, enskri pou reyinyon an ak lyen ki anwo a. Pou gade l an dirèk, vizite Bibliyotèk Central Plas la (45 Pearl Street). Entèpretasyon an ap disponib an kreyòl Ayisyen ak an Espanyòl. Gratis epi louvri pou tout moun! Acompáñenos a la presentación de un abogado de inmigración de De Novo sobre el Estatus de Protección Temporal (TPS). Hablaremos sobre los siguientes temas: cómo renovar su TPS permiso de trabajo e información de viaje apoyos legales y recursos disponibles Para ver esta presentación en Zoom, regístrese en la reunión usando el enlace anterior. Para verla en vivo, visite la Biblioteca de Central Square 45 Pearl Street, Cambridge Habrá interpretación en criollo haitiano y español. ¡Entrada libre y gratuita!

title: Sewing 101 (Main)
description: In this 90-minute workshop, you’ll learn the basics of sewing machine operation and safety. This session will cover machine setup, basic functions, threading the machine, reloading the bobbin, sewing straight stitches, and recognizing when stitch tension has gone awry. We’ll also cover some safety best practices when operating a sewing machine. As we learn together, we’ll work on a simple sewing project—a drawstring bag—which most students will be able to complete by the end of the class. You must complete Hive Safety Training before registering for this workshop.

Presented in Partnership with Cambridge Insight Meditation Center (CIMC). Rooted in the Theravada Buddhist tradition,CIMC is a welcoming refuge and teaching Center for all who seek inner peace through the liberating practice of Insight Meditation (vipassana). title: Watercolor Workshop (Boudreau)
description: In this class you will be introduced to painting with watercolor, including techniques in color mixing, observational painting, and composition. At your own pace you will learn how to paint still life using watercolor in a relaxed and welcoming environment. This class will cover wet on wet and wet on dry techniques, masking, pressing, shading and light techniques, ink washes, and pattern making. You will come away from this class with many beautiful watercolor paintings of your own and a greater understanding and appreciation for the medium of watercolor. This class is suitable for beginners and can be adjusted for all levels of experience. This class is for adults. This class is taught by Brooke Lambert. Brooke is a professional printmaker and painter. She holds a BFA from Massachusetts College of Art and Design and shows her work widely in New England, New York, and beyond. Brooke works in Studio 291 at Western Avenue Studios & Lofts in Lowell, MA. She is currently represented by The Society of American Graphic Artists and Equity Gallery in New York, NY and Galaray House, contemporary art gallery in Lexington, MA. She has thirteen years of teaching experience and currently teaches adult art workshops and holds artist demos at several locations in New England.

Copies of this month's book are available at the Children's Desk. Copies of this month's book are available at the Children's Desk. title: Sewing 101 (Main)
description: In this 90-minute workshop, you’ll learn the basics of sewing machine operation and safety. This session will cover machine setup, basic functions, threading the machine, reloading the bobbin, sewing straight stitches, and recognizing when stitch tension has gone awry. We’ll also cover some safety best practices when operating a sewing machine. As we learn together, we’ll work on a simple sewing project—a drawstring bag—which most students will be able to complete by the end of the class. You must complete Hive Safety Training before registering for this workshop.

title: AI and Us Town Hall: Your Voice Belongs in the Future of AI (Main)
description: AI is the most transformative technology of our time, yet decisions about its future are being shaped by a small group of people. As AI becomes embedded in our daily lives, the voices of young people, families, educators, and community members matter more than ever. Join us for an inclusive, intergenerational gathering where we explore what is at stake, what is possible, how we can collectively shape a more humane and equitable future in the age of AI. AI and Us Showcase — Discover how young people, researchers, and community organizations are shaping AI for humanity. Town Hall Conversations — Hear from thought leaders and youth voices on why our participation in AI’s future is not optional. Community Commitment Wall — Add your hope or promise for a future where everyone belongs in the story of AI. AI is still young. Its future is not yet written. Let’s shape it together. Registration is required to participate in this event.

title: Aging with Mindfulness (Virtual)
description: This program, led by Zeenat Potia, will introduce and utilize mindfulness techniques to help us examine and regulate everyday life changes with a focus on aging. Participants will learn and benefit from the development of a mindfulness practice to enable responding to getting older in a calm, clear and thoughtful manner. Presented in Partnership with Cambridge Insight Meditation Center (CIMC). Rooted in the Theravada Buddhist tradition,CIMC is a welcoming refuge and teaching Center for all who seek inner peace through the liberating practice of Insight Meditation (vipassana). As an urban center, and now as an online community, CIMC is dedicated to the integration of practice into every aspect of community and daily life. Visit the CIMC Website. Registration is required. This is a virtual event. A Zoom link will be sent to all registered participants 1 hour before the event.

title: Sewing 101 (Main)
description: In this 90-minute workshop, you’ll learn the basics of sewing machine operation and safety. This session will cover machine setup, basic functions, threading the machine, reloading the bobbin, sewing straight stitches, and recognizing when stitch tension has gone awry. We’ll also cover some safety best practices when operating a sewing machine. As we learn together, we’ll work on a simple sewing project—a drawstring bag—which most students will be able to complete by the end of the class. You must complete Hive Safety Training before registering for this workshop.

title: Aging with Mindfulness (Virtual)
description: This program, led by Zeenat Potia, will introduce and utilize mindfulness techniques to help us examine and regulate everyday life changes with a focus on aging. Participants will learn and benefit from the development of a mindfulness practice to enable responding to getting older in a calm, clear and thoughtful manner. Presented in Partnership with Cambridge Insight Meditation Center (CIMC). Rooted in the Theravada Buddhist tradition,CIMC is a welcoming refuge and teaching Center for all who seek inner peace through the liberating practice of Insight Meditation (vipassana). As an urban center, and now as an online community, CIMC is dedicated to the integration of practice into every aspect of community and daily life. Visit the CIMC Website. Registration is required. This is a virtual event. A Zoom link will be sent to all registered participants 1 hour before the event.

We will help you identify birds, learn birdwatching tips and tricks, and familiarize yourself with migratory birds as well as those that can be spotted all year round. A limited supply of binoculars will be available. The walk will meet at the Collins Branch Library at 64 Aberdeen Ave at 10:15 am. We will walk to Mt. Auburn Cemetery together (about a five minute walk). Please try to be on time as we will leave shortly after 10:15! Registration is required. This event can only accommodate a certain number of participants. One registration is good for one person. If you do not register, you cannot participate. Those on the waitlist will be contacted if a space becomes available.

title: Serger Training (Main)
description: Are you an intermediate or advanced sewer? This class will cover serger machine setup, threading a serger, and identifying correct tension settings with different types of fabric. You will learn about ways to use our Elna Extend 864 Air serger to take your sewing skills to the next level by producing special finishing styles, hemming, trimming and assembling your garments. Up to two patrons can register for this class. This class is designed for patrons who have prior experience using a sewing machine to complete many types of fiber arts projects. If you are new to machine sewing, we recommend you take our Sewing 101 workshop before using our serger.

title: Zing Laser Cutting 101 (Main)
description: Learn how to use our Epilog Zing—an industry-standard laser cutting machine. Complete this workshop to earn a badge for the Zing laser cutter. With a badge, you can reserve the Epilog Zing to use on our equipment booking page at designated times. Note: The Epilog Zing laser cutter and Glowforge laser cutter require separate trainings. You must participate in the Glowforge workshop in order to operate our Glowforge Pro laser cutter. You must complete Hive Safety Training before registering for this workshop.

You can use our 1-inch button maker, 2.5 inch button maker, 3-D Doodle pens, or Janome sewing machines. The Library will provide basic supplies. This drop-in program is for people who feel comfortable using these machines on their own. The Library will not provide instruction. Anyone wishing to use the sewing machines must have completed a Sewing 101 training through the Library. Children under the age of 12 must be accompanied by an adult.

title: MCBA Book Group (Central Square)
description: Did you know you can vote for a winner in the Massachusetts Children's Book Award each year? Join us the 1st Wednesday of each month as we read and discuss some of the MCBA nominated books. Cast your vote for your favorite nominated title, right here at the library. This program is for kids in 4th, 5th and 6th grade (or equivalent ages). Registration is required. For more information, please contact jpittel@cambridgema.gov. This month we're reading The Swifts by Beth Lincoln (Dutton, 2023). Limited copies of the book will be available at the Central Square Library. Pizza will be provided!

title: Brewery Book Club (Lamplighter)
description: You’re invited to our January Brewery Book Club, where Lamplighter and the Cambridge Public Library team up to highlight contemporary works from marginalized voices while having a beer. We meet at Lamplighter Brewing Co., 284 Broadway, in the back taproom. This month we’ll read The Safekeep by Yael van der Wouden. Copies of the book are available at the Main Library Q&A Desk. The e-book and digital audiobook can be borrowed through the Libby app. We’ll gather in the Lamplighter back taproom to discuss the book, what we learned from it, what we found ourselves touched by, and all other thoughts. Registration not required. Link to Lamplighter Eventbrite coming soon.

title: Great Books Book Group (Main/Virtual)
description: This week's selection: Vladimir Nabokov, Lolita Reading Interests: We concentrate on Great Books in the following areas: a long novel over the summer, two sections of poetry and short stories, a book of the Bible, a Shakespeare play, an ancient and modern drama, a work of science, a smaller work of fiction, an even smaller work of fiction, and a rotating mix of politics, philosophy, and religion. Authors read in the past five years include Dickens, Keats and Yeats, O'Connor and Munro, Ecclesiastes, Sophocles and August Wilson, Darwin, Austen, Duras, The Federalist Papers, and Arendt. How to get the print book: Copies of the reading are set aside at the Main Library. Visit the Main Library at 449 Broadway during current service hours and a staff member can help you get a copy. How to register: Registration is required. Click the registration link below to register. This is a hybrid event. A Zoom link will be sent to all registered participants 1 hour before the event. For more information, contact Drew Griffin (dgriffin@cambridgema.gov)

How to get the print book: Copies of the print book are set aside at the Main Library Q&A Desk on the ground floor. Visit the Main Library at 449 Broadway during service hours and a staff member can help you check out a copy. title: 51st Annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day Lecture (Hybrid)
description: Join us for the 52ND Annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Lecture with Dr. Brandon M. Terry. Dr. Terry is the John L. Loeb Associate Professor of the Social Sciences at Harvard University and Codirector of the Institute on Policing, Incarceration, and Public Safety at the Hutchins Center for African and African American Research. He is the author of Shattered Dreams, Infinite Hope: A Tragic Vision of the Civil Rights Movement and is coeditor, with Tommie Shelby, of To Shape a New World: Essays on the Political Philosophy of Martin Luther King, Jr. and editor of Fifty Years Since MLK. This event is cosponsored by the Mayor's Office, the City Manager's Office, Cambridge Public Library, and the Cambridge Public Library. Registration is required.

title: Cookbook Club (Collins
description: January Selections: Love Japan : recipes from our Japanese American kitchen by Sawako Okochi & Aaron Israel with Gabriella Gershenson and The gaijin cookbook : Japanese recipes from a chef, father, eater, and lifelong outsider by Ivan Orkin and Chris Ying. Join friends and neighbors for a potluck! Try a recipe and bring your results or thoughts to share and discuss with other cooks. All experience levels welcome. No need to bring a dish to join. Books will be available for pick up at the Boudreau and Collins Branches during library hours. This event will take place indoors at the Collins Branch (64 Aberdeen Ave.) For more information contact Liz at edanner@cambridgema.gov or call the Collins Branch at 617-349-4021.

description: Writers of all experience levels are invited to join a casual, peer-supported writing group. In this group, participants take turns bringing short in-progress or completed pieces of any genre. The group reads several pieces each month, sharing feedback and constructive criticism in a supportive and inclusive environment. We may practice in-class writing exercises and read samples of published writing as time allows. Registration is required. NOTE: Registration is for this month's meeting only. For more information, please email Susannah at sbtkacz@cambridgema.gov.

This evening dance party will be full of maracas and tambourines, colorful scarves, and lots of movement and dance. Recommended for ages 0-5 and their caregivers. For more information, please call the Central Square Branch Children's Room at 617-349-4012.

title: Your Fat Friend Documentary Screening
description: Join the Central Square Branch Library for a screening of Jeanie Finlay's documentary Your Fat Friend. Made over 6 years, acclaimed director Jeanie Finlay charts the rise of writer and activist Aubrey Gordon from anonymous blogger to NYTimes best selling author and beloved podcaster. Her aim? A paradigm shift in the way we see fat people and the fat on our own bodies. Her life changing work has brought her an ardent, international audience but also threats to her life. One of her biggest challenges is getting her parents to listen. Your Fat Friend, a film about fatness, family, the complexities of change and the deep, messy feeling we hold about our bodies. yrfatfriendfilm.com / @yrfatfriendfilm

title: The First President and the First People: Washington in the Native Northeast (Main/Virtual)
description: To mark the 250th anniversaries of the American Revolution and the founding of the United States, a coalition of local non-profits and government agencies will present Washington in American Memory, a seven-part speaker series. Explore how Americans have remembered, reinterpreted, and reshaped the meaning of the American Revolution from 1776 to today, featuring: Colin Gordon Calloway, author of The Indian World of George Washington: The First President, the First Americans, and the Birth of the Nation and the John Kimball, Jr. 1943 Professor of History and Professor of Native American Studies at Dartmouth College

title: Great Books Book Group (Main/Virtual)
description: This week's selection: Tony Kushner, Angels in America Reading Interests: We concentrate on Great Books in the following areas: a long novel over the summer, two sections of poetry and short stories, a book of the Bible, a Shakespeare play, an ancient and modern drama, a work of science, a smaller work of fiction, an even smaller work of fiction, and a rotating mix of politics, philosophy, and religion. Authors read in the past five years include Dickens, Keats and Yeats, O'Connor and Munro, Ecclesiastes, Sophocles and August Wilson, Darwin, Austen, Duras, The Federalist Papers, and Arendt. How to get the print book: Copies of the reading are set aside at the Main Library. Visit the Main Library at 449 Broadway during current service hours and a staff member can help you get a copy. How to register: Registration is required. Click the registration link below to register. This is a hybrid event. A Zoom link will be sent to all registered participants 1 hour before the event. For more information, contact Drew Griffin (dgriffin@cambridgema.gov)

description: Boston based garage punk featuring ex members of the Tampoffs, Tokyo Electron and the Wongs. Garage Rock N Roll from Boston featuring members of Andy California, The Monseurs and Pledge Pins

title: The David Haas Group: A Coalition of the Willing
description: free admission / 7pm start / seated Recorded Live@LilyPad, Coalition of the Willing on 10.27.24 The group’s album “Formal Motion” will be available at the gig.

title: Louis Thélot Fusion 5tet
description: $15 @ the door / $10 students / 9:30 doors / 10pm show This fusion project is a quintet led by French jazz violinist Louis Thélot, performing his original music, with Paul Vanier (keys), Aki Oliviero (guitar), Ferran Rico (bass) and Ben Fig (drums). The music is a fusion that draws on a wide range of multicultural influences. Louis Thélot is a French violinist, composer and arranger who grew up in the city of Lyon (France). He entered the National Conservatory of Lyon (CNSMD) in 2019, where he studied classical music with the world-class violinist Marc Danel (first violin of the Danel Quartet). In the meantime, he studied jazz and other music with Rémi Crambes, an outstanding contemporary jazz violinist and composer. He performed in France and other European countries in many different places, such as the 'Opéra de Lyon', the 'Philharmonie de Paris', or the 'Jazz à Vienne' or Lake Garda festivals, playing in symphonic orchestras, chamber orchestras, as a soloist, as well as a jazz/rock band leader and composer. In 2022 he obtained a scholarship to enter the Berklee College of Music, where he studied jazz performance and composition until his graduation in Spring 2025.

title: The Tall Trio
description: Every Monday night, the Lilypad’s Tall Trio warms up the stage for a night full of Jazz Legends.

title: Jerry Bergonzi Quartet
description: Jerry Bergonzi, Tenor Saxophone A fine, high-powered tenor saxophonist with a tone influenced by John Coltrane, a mastery of chord changes, and a strong musical imagination, Jerry Bergonzi has long had an underground following in the Boston area. He started on clarinet when he was eight, switching to alto at 12, and finally to tenor two years later. Bergonzi was inspired early on by Sonny Rollins, Coltrane, and Hank Mobley. He attended Lowell University and then after graduation played electric bass in local bands behind singers and strippers, saving up enough money to move to New York in 1972. After struggling in the Big Apple for seven years and gaining some recognition as a member of Two Generations of Brubeck and of the Dave Brubeck Quartet (with whom he appeared on several Concord albums during 1979-1981), Bergonzi moved back to Boston in 1981, where he developed a strong career both as a tenorman and as an educator. He has since led several groups (including two called Con Brio and Gonz) and recorded for the Plug, Not Fat, Red, and Blue Note labels. — By Scott Yanow, AllMusic

title: The Fringe
description: The Fringe originally formed back in 1971 by tenor-saxophonist George Garzone, bassist Richard Appleman, and drummer Bob Gullotti as an outlet for their free jazz improvisations, The Fringe have entertained and enlightened Boston area jazz audiences for over 50 years. Bassist Appleman left the band in 1985 to become Chairman of the Bass Department at Berklee College and was replaced by veteran bassist John Lockwood. Bob Gullotti passed away in 2020 and is remembered as one of the greatest jazz drummers of his generation. Francisco Mela, now on drums, graciously fills the space Bob left behind. Along with their impressive tenure with The Fringe, Garzone, Lockwood, and Mela are in great demand as session players and have played with many of the greats of contemporary jazz. Along with keeping up with a busy performance schedule, each of them are well-respected educators helping to inspire the jazz musicians of tomorrow. George Garzone, Tenor Saxophone Lineup subject to change without notice

title: Berklee Strings Takeover with Honeyjaw and the Berklee Contemporary Cello Ensemble
description: $10-20 suggested donation / 7:30 doors / 8pm start / seated The Berklee Strings Takeover features two genre-defying student ensembles from the strings department playing an extremely wide range of styles and genres including metal, math rock, folk/roots, classical, alt rock, funk and jazz, all on traditional acoustic string instruments- come check it out! Featuring performances by Honeyjaw and the Berklee Contemporary Cello Ensemble. Honeyjaw is a group of Berklee students interpreting math rock and metal through the lens of roots instrumentation. They will be featuring songs by the Violinist, Kemedy Hauser, Megadeth, Black Sabbath, Chon, and Tool. Led by Strings Department faculty member and cellist Jeremy Harman, the Berklee Contemporary Cello Ensemble defies genres and convention, performing an eclectic mix of music including compositions and songs by Villa-Lobos, A Perfect Circle, Soundgarden, Vulfpeck, Weezer and original arrangements by members of the ensemble.

title: Jam Session with Nick Brust and Liz Sinn
description: $15 / $10 students / 10pm doors / 10:30 -12:30 show / seated Nick and Liz have put together a dynamic quartet comprised of some of Boston's finest to perform some uncommon standards and fiery original repertoire. The house band will play a set up front followed by an open jam session. Wielding a unique, incisive but soulful voice as an improviser and composer, Boston-based jazz saxophonist Nicholas Brust (pronounced “Bruhst”) has established his voice in the world of modern improvised music. He has found his niche as a bandleader and sideman, taking advantage of the numerous textures and combinations available in the traditional jazz small-group format. Brust has performed and/or recorded with numerous highly acclaimed musicians, including Lage Lund, Gilad Hekselman (with bassist Jon Latona), Mark Ferber (with pianist Francesca Prihasti), The Peter Silver Big Band (sharing the stage with Roy Hargrove, Jimmy Owens, Steve Wilson and others), guitarist Ben Eunson, Kristina Koller (appearing in her Quintet at the 2020 NYC Winter Jazz Fest), and many others. Nicholas is currently on faculty at New England Conservatory as part of its Prep/Continuing Education division in addition to being an Artslink Teaching Artist for Berklee College of Music’s City Music program. Pianist and composer Liz Sinn has become an in-demand collaborator in New England’s vibrant music scene, her journey rooted at Berklee College of Music. Though specializing in jazz, Liz brings versatility across genres, including various Latin American music styles, classical, musical theater, and pop. While in Boston, Liz has had the opportunity to perform with many notable musicians, including GRAMMY Award winners Neal Smith and Charlie Rosen’s 8-Bit Big Band, as well as internationally recognized artists Il Divo, Chloë Agnew of Celtic Woman, and Rafael Barata. Her skills as an arranger and copyist have also led to collaborations with renowned Latin American artists Andrés Cepeda and Daymé Arocena, showcasin

title: Hatha Yoga
description: $10 - $20 sliding scale / all levels / every Wednesday This class is appropriate for all students, from beginners to advanced Yogis alike. (cash or venmo accepted upon arrival) The Integral Yoga method was designed to draw the practitioner into a physical and mental stillness that leads to an experience of one’s true nature— peace and joy. Please visit lilypadinman.com/yoga for more details on Integral Yoga!

title: Bert Seager's Heart of Hearing
description: Bert Seager’s Heart of Hearing is a-jazz quartet made up of piano, tenor-saxophone, upright-bass, and drums whose aim is to bring listeners into the heart of improvised jazz. The joyful expression of this musical intimacy, the shimmering transparency of the sound, and the sense that these musicians are as much involved in listening as in playing makes for compelling and memorable performances.

title: Gill Aharon Trio
description: Inspired by the cartoon music of the 50s and 60s, the drive of Led Zeppelin, the genius and humor of Frank Zappa, the perfection of Bach, the relentlessness of Ligeti, the courage of Medeski, Martin and Wood, the jam of Phish live, the beauty of the Beatles and the immersive nature of music, I am in pursuit of truth through music. “Sometimes I think of us musicians as kids playing in order to learn how to be adults, but we can just keep playing. The game of playing music together is too much fun to make it work. With that in mind, I refuse to write arrangements. I never want my friends and bandmates to feel obliged to do anything. - Gill Aharon

title: The Lilypad Variety Show
description: Music, Comedy, Dance, Poetry, Art, Film & More. Always Seeking New Talent, Come Perform & Bring Your Friends! hosted by Jesse Gallagher ~ @jessegallagher.tv on instagram

title: Adam Hersh Trio ft. Gary Novak
description: The Adam Hersh Trio presents original jazz fusion. Influenced by some of the most innovative minds in the genre—Chick Corea, Billy Childs, & Wayne Shorter—the group uplifts new creative voices with Adam Hersh on piano & Max Gerl on bass, accompanied by Corea & Holdsworth's alum Gary Novak on drums. LA based pianist, keyboardist, & composer Adam Hersh was born in Castaic, CA. Since graduating from CSUN, Adam has been active in the LA jazz scene, performing & recording with musicians like Bob Sheppard, Mike Moreno, Warren Wolf, Munir Hossn, Bill Holman, Gary Novak, Billy Childs, Andrew Renfroe, Joe LaBarbera, & Gene Coye. Adam is a versatile musician, adept at learning & playing modern, fusion, & straight ahead originals & standards.

title: Ava Rush / Isabella Gueck / Sofia Devitt
description: $12 at the door / 10pm doors / 10:15 start / standing Three standout singer-songwriters share the stage for a night of expressive performances, original music, and unforgettable energy. Ava Rush is a pop-country rock singer-songwriter from Long Island, New York whose music aims to show a sense of vulnerability that connects with her audience. Through her evocative lyrics and powerful vocals, Ava’s songs demonstrate her raw emotions and ability to stay true to her unique artistic vision. Ava released her first song “Right In Front Of You” in March of 2023 and has since been working on recording her debut album, which contains songs of various topics such as feeling used and discarded, love and heartbreak, and growing up. As well as recording her album, she has also been playing shows with her band around Boston at venues such as The Middle East, The Lily Pad, The Burren, Caffe Nero, The Red Room, and more. Ava’s recently released a single called, “Lie All Night” on September 26th and has more singles coming out this fall and spring. She is excited to release her album soon and to continue to grow her artistry. Isabella Gueck is an artist and songwriter who finds strength in vulnerability. Inspired by artists like Lizzy McAlpine, Leith Ross, and Olivia Barton, her songwriting fosters empathy in her listeners. As she navigates her early twenties, Isabella’s music explores themes of identity, love, and the messy transition from girlhood to adulthood. Through the vulnerability of her music, Isabella aims to illuminate the shared human experience, encouraging self-compassion and reminding listeners they’re not alone. Sofia Devitt is a colorful driving force in alternative rock. Based in Boston, Massachusetts, Sofia is a vocal powerhouse that blends the sounds of 70’s rock with modern indie pop. With her infectious energy and a fresh new sound, Sofia’s catchy melodies are bound to linger in your subconscious. From groovy dance numbers to angsty ballads, there’s a little bi

title: Julien Kasper
description: Acclaimed guitar virtuoso Julien Kasper is a unique musician who has absorbed multiple genres into his musical DNA – rock, jazz, blues, funk, classical – to create a voice as a composer and improviser that is truly his own. Lush psychedelia, harmonic sophistication, nuanced phrasing, and Hendrix influenced “Band of Gypsies” era funk-rock are all on the table at a Julien Kasper concert. He brings his trio to featuring legendary Boston musicians Jesse Williams on bass and Zac Casher on drums. “Exquisite tones, masterful execution, and innate soulfulness drive this jazzy, funky, bluesy, Sco-and-Beck-meet-Hendrix-for-drinks-at-the-Harvard-Psychedelic-Club instrumental joyride.” “While it’s hard to categorize what Kasper does, he’s certainly one of the most imaginative composers and players working with the guitar today.”

title: Hatha Yoga w/ Live Music
description: Experience the magic of a moving meditation with Integral Yoga instructor Parashakti. This class is approriate for all students, from beginners to advanced or seasoned yogis. Dress comfortably, and bring a cozy blanket if you’d like! (cash or venmo accepted at the door) Musical accompaniment on the Grand Piano provided by Jesse Gallagher, along with selections from his meditation album "The Inner Sound."

title: free collective disco
description: free admission / 4:30 start / all ages & family friendly Disco as meditation, experimental community joy and expression Drop by to dance, improvise, celebrate, seek! Enjoy a 2-hour playlist of participatory possibilities, centered around work by Dinosaur L / Arthur Russell. A library of toy percussion will be available to borrow and play during the event. We also welcome any pocket-sized sound makers you might like to bring from home. Bring your compassion & mutualism & curiosity, join as you are or as you dream to be. Host McMillan Ilderton is a social worker and performer who was born in the mid-1980s and has lived in Eastern MA since 2010. They enjoy creating community connections and creative possibilities!

title: Live at the Druid Presents "Will Woodson & Caitlin Finley"
description: $20 at door / $15 advance / 7pm doors / seated & standing Live Music from Will Woodson (Uileann Pipes & Flute) & Caitlin Finley (Fiddle) presented by Lilypad’s friend and neighbor, The Druid Pub. The Druid Pub in Inman Square, renowned for its authentic Irish atmosphere and live traditional music, is launching a new concert series spotlighting global roots music. The concert series will take place next door at The Lilypad, a cozy venue in Inman Square, offering an intimate setting for this special event. Will Woodson (flute, uilleann pipes) and Caitlin Finley (fiddle) play sparky and driving traditional Irish music that’s grounded in the textures and rhythms of the rich Irish-American soundscape of the 1920s and 30s. With roots in the living Irish musical cultures of Boston, New York City, and Philadelphia, and a tremendous admiration for the first generation of recorded Irish musicians, the duo conjures up the sounds of the dance halls, vaudeville theaters, and house sessions central to Irish-American music from the first half of the twentieth century. In 2019, the two recorded their debut album, “The Glory Reel” alongside box player and piano accompanist Chris “Junior” Stevens, which Dan Neely of the Irish Echo called “a fabulous album from three of Irish America’s finest.” During the pandemic years, the two made “The Phonograph Project”, a Patreon-supported series examining 78 recordings of traditional Irish music made in New York City in the 1920s and 30s. More recently, they’ve made musical appearances at the St. Louis Tionól, the Patrick J. Touhey Memorial Weekend in Boston and the Ward Archives “Archiving Irish America” conference in Milwaukee. Cait and Will live in Portland, Maine.

title: The Gold Ounce
description: $10 admission / 7pm doors / 7:30 start / seated & standing Join the funk-jazz instrumental group The Gold Ounce for an evening of expansive exploration, including an entirely improvised set. The Gold Ounce is an instrumental funk-jazz group comprised of drums, guitar, and bass. Much like a jazz ensemble, The Gold Ounce reimagines, expands, and improvises over original tunes and standards. Our overall purpose is to stimulate the ears and spirit by embracing the power, joy, and sense of discovery in our improvisations.

title: Pepita Lo-Fi Sunday
description: Lo-Fi Sundays are here! Stop by the “secret” back taproom of our sweet little cafe space every Sunday morning for a peaceful, unplugged experience… Need a bit of quiet time? The Lamplighter + Pepita team is here to bring you a little slice of calm to your week. From here on out, we will open the back taproom from 8am-2pm on Sunday mornings for a new, regular event we’re calling Lo Fi Sunday. Think of it as a designated calming, quiet zone just for our Pepita patrons. We’ll play chill, ambient music to set the vibe, and folks are encouraged to read, work, study, etc. with minimal talking preferred. Grab a coffee and cozy up in the back taproom at our 284 Broadway location to soak up that tranquil energy or to get a jump start on the week ahead. Your weekend brunch plans have never been more relaxing! P.S. If you’re not feeling quiet time, the front taproom will remain open as usual for normal operations.

title: Jeopardy Bar League
description: JEOPARDY! Bar League, the official bar trivia experience from America’s Favorite Quiz Show, is coming to Lamplighter!

title: Broadway Trivia
description: Attend one of our most beloved, longest standing brewery traditions: Trivia Tuesday! Every Tuesday swing by our Broadway taproom for our weekly trivia night. It’s free to compete, and winners get beer money. Here’s how it works: show up with your team of 2 – 6 players starting at 7:00 pm, when we’ll open the doors to the back taproom. Head down the hallway to the back, then snag a seat. All seating is first come first serve, so we recommend arriving early – there generally is a line! The game will start at 7:30 pm, and is about two hours long (with plenty of beer breaks, of course). Questions rotate every week, and cover categories ranging from history, politics, sports, movies, pop culture, music, and more. At the end of the game, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place teams will be awarded Lamplighter gift cards – good for usage in either of our taprooms and at Pepita Coffee Co. In addition to Trivia Tuesday at our Broadway taproom, we also host weekly trivia at our CX taproom. That game takes place on Monday evenings, and is also free to join for teams of 2 – 6. We’d love to see you at either or both! Hungry? Munch on our signature giant soft pretzels or some crunchy nachos, which are available Tuesday evenings only. You’re also always welcome to bring your own food or order in, ask our staff for their favorite local recommendations. See you at trivia night! You must be 21+ attend, all guests will be asked to show valid government ID. Questions? Get in touch! You can reach us at events@lamplighterbrewing.com

title: Pepita Lo-Fi Friday
description: Lo-Fi Fridays are here! Just like our Lo-Fi weekends but now during the work week! Stop by the “secret” back taproom of our sweet little cafe space every Friday morning for a quiet sanctuary of productivity and peace. Need a bit of quiet time? The Lamplighter + Pepita team are here to bring you a little slice of calm. From here on out, we will open the back taproom from 8am-2pm on Friday mornings for Lo Fi Fridays. title: Brewery Tour & Tasting
description: Break out your notebook and freshly sharpened No. 2 pencils because we’re going back to school! We're offering brewery tours at our original 284 Broadway location on the first Saturday of every month. Space is limited, so snag your spot right here by purchasing a ticket. Our knowledgeable team will lead you on an interactive, behind-the-scenes tour of the production floor at Lamp, where you’ll learn the essentials of craft beer-making, and how it all works at our compact, Cambridge-based facility. You'll also taste your way through the brewing process, sampling three of our current favorite draft pour picks, plus a special bonus beer to start the sipping syllabus. Will you graduate top of your class? Either way, we think you’ll find your new favorite subject. Each ticket includes: 🍻One 6 oz welcome beer, plus 3 - 5 oz flight glass-sized samples 🚶🏼A 60 min guided tasting and behind-the-scenes brewery tour 📝 Beer School "quiz" and informational answer key 📚 A Lamplighter Beer School diploma :) Questions? Get in touch! events@lamplighterbrewing.com. Please note that this event is 21+ and all guests will be asked to show a valid government-issued ID. Refund Policy We understand that plans sometimes change. If you provide us with more than 24 hours' notice prior to the event start time, we will issue a full refund to your original payment method. Within 24 hours of the start time, we will offer a refund in the form of credit to be used for a future ticketed event hosted by Lamplighter, valid for 1 year. Please note that Eventbrite fees, including processing and service fees, are nonrefundable as they are charged by Eventbrite and not under the control of Lamplighter. Please request refunds through Eventbrite, on your order confirmation page.

title: Pottery with a Purpose - Holiday Edition
description: Grab a drink and join us for this inclusive, beginner-friendly pottery workshop at Lamplighter! Holiday Edition: Add a little handmade holiday magic to your season by sculpting functional festive decor or heartfelt gifts from clay. Make ornaments, candle holders, holiday trays, mini trees, or whatever you dream up. Think cozy, joyful, messily creative energy, because the best gifts are always the ones you make yourself. You’ll learn hand-building techniques and shape your own one-of-a-kind clay cup, perfect for coffee, tea, beer or whatever warms your soul. Bonus: it's just as satisfying to drink from as it is to make! Delicious drinks available for purchase! This workshop is 21+ only.

title: Gingerbread House Competition
description: LEARN MORE AND SIGN UP HERE Join us for our first-ever Gingerbread House Building Competition. Participate as a contestant or come for free as a spectator to cheer on the builders and enjoy the drink specials. A portion of ticket sales will support our community partner, Project Bread. And there will be plenty of our collaboration beer, Bread Zeppelin, a Ginger-Spiced Ale to enjoy as well. Contestants will get a base kit of building supplies (but you're free to bring any supplemental materials needed to enhance your designs). The kit includes four walls, a roof, icing, and assorted candies. You'll have an hour to build your masterpiece before the judging begins. There will be a winner chosen by our esteemed panel of judges, and one audience favorite. Test your skills, get in the holiday spirit, and support a good cause!

title: Pepita Lo-Fi Saturday
description: Lo-Fi Saturdays are here! Stop by the “secret” back taproom of our sweet little cafe space every Saturday morning for a peaceful, unplugged experience… Need a bit of quiet time? The Lamplighter + Pepita team is here to bring you a little slice of calm to your week. From here on out, we will open the back taproom from 8am-2pm on Saturday mornings for a new, regular event we’re calling Lo Fi Saturdays. Think of it as a designated calming, quiet zone just for our Pepita patrons. We’ll play chill, ambient music to set the vibe, and folks are encouraged to read, work, study, etc. with minimal talking preferred. Grab a coffee and cozy up in the back taproom at our 284 Broadway location to soak up that tranquil energy or to get a jump start on the week ahead. Your weekend brunch plans have never been more relaxing! P.S. If you’re not feeling quiet time, the front taproom will remain open as usual for normal operations.

title: Hubbub Comedy
description: GRAB YOUR TICKETS HERE What’s all the hubbub at Lamplighter CX? A great line up of Boston’s best comics! Want to know their deepest secrets? Write a question at the door and they may answer it live on-stage! Join us at our Cambridge Crossing location at 110 N First St, Cambridge for unlimited laughs and flowing beer taps! We are excited to be partnering with our favorite Cambridge based comedy group, Hubbub Comedy. This night features local comics performing in an intimate setting – delivering a memorable, can’t-miss standup comedy experience. The show starts at 8pm, with doors at 7:30pm. $15 tickets online or at the door. You must be 21+ attend, all guests will be asked to show valid government ID.

title: Brewery Yoga
description: Buy your tickets on Eventbrite! Looking for some healthy weekend plans? Join us for a Sunday morning brewery yoga class at Lamplighter Brewing Co.’s Cambridge Crossing (CX) taproom. We’ll gather in the light-filled upstairs taproom for a gentle flow. Space is limited, and reservations are required. Save your spot through Eventbrite here! All yoga levels are welcome! This class is great for beginners, as well as for experienced yogis. We’ll lead you through a guided flow with a focus on stretching, breathing, and light activity – you might work up a light sweat, but nothing too strenuous. Please plan on bringing your own yoga mat. If you don’t have a mat, a large beach towel works as well. The class takes place in our upstairs taproom at Lamplighter Brewing Co.’s CX location (110 N First St, Cambridge MA). Your ticket includes full access to the yoga class as well as a beer, cold brew coffee, or kombucha. Parking: There is street parking available, or the parking garage is available for $10 with Lamplighter validation. Show your ticket to a bartender before or after class to validate! This event is 21+ and all guests must show a valid government-issued ID. Questions? Get in touch: events@lamplighterbrewing.com.

title: Candle Making Workshop
description: Join us at the vibrant Lamplighter Brewing Co. CX Taproom in Cambridge for our Crafts & Pints Candle-Making Series—a relaxing and creative night out where you’ll pour your own soy candles and enjoy great company (and even better beer). 📍 Lamplighter CX TaproomLocation: 110 N First Street, Cambridge, MA🕕 Time: 7:00 PM – 9:00 PM💵 Price: $39 plus Eventbrite fees🎨 Theme: Crafts & Pints Series 🚫 Please note: We do not offer a one-candle option. Tickets are per person and include two candles. 🎟️ Spots are limited! Grab your tickets and join us for a cozy, crafty night at Lamplighter Brewing Co.’s CX Taproom!

title: Sushi Making Cooking Class
description: With over two decades of sushi-making expertise stretching from California to Boston, Chef Harold is ready to share his knowledge with you. This sushi fundamentals class is free of gluten, nuts and dairy, and focuses on medium inside-out rolls, or uramaki, and hand rolls, or temaki. Begin the hands-on class with miso soup, then move on to mastering sushi rolling. You'll start with a shrimp tempura hand roll, then craft a delicious sweet potato hand roll. To finish, you'll learn the secrets to making a spicy tuna roll.

title: Spoondrift
description: Described as “electric Americana with a psychedelic tinge”, Spoondrift has taken the Boston jam band scene by storm with their inspired and contemplative original songs, groove-based improvisation, and energetic covers. Consisting of Mike Sim (guitar, vocals), Jason Oberstein (guitar, vocals), Ian Svagdis (drums, vocals), Alex Lyons (keyboards, vocals), and Alec Hovey (electric bass, vocals), the group was formed out of their love of music and mutual respect for all who blazed the trail before them. title: Wicked Queer! Stand-Up Comedy
description: GET YOUR TICKETS HERE! LGBTQ+ stand-up comedy from local queer talent, with a super sexy surprise headliner. Come find out ;) LGBTQ+ cuties do it better. Featuring Boston's hottest and most hilarious talent, Wicked Queer Stand-up Comedy combines local comedians, incredible food, and a super sexy surprise headliner. You're in for a night full of queer community and riotous laughter. Portico Brewing will be pouring beers and seltzers, serving tacos all night! Doors: 7:30PMComedy Show: 8:00 - 9:00PMHang Until Close! (at 10pm)

title: Pixel Party
description: Build a wooden model of an iconic Nintendo character! Each participant will be given a set of painted wooden blocks that correspond with their chosen character. You will then be guided step by step on how to glue the blocks together to make a wooden model of a character from the 8-bit era of gaming. All materials will be provided and no experience is necessary. Final sculptures will vary in size. The tallest is Samus (13 inches) and the shortest are Mario & Link (each 6.7 inches). If you do not finish your sculpture during the event, you are welcome to take everything you need to finish it at home. If you would like to build a character that is not listed in the dropdown menu, feel free to email robertpatricklynch@gmail.com with requests. This is an all ages event. Children under 13 should be signed up at their parent/guardian's discretion. They will need adult supervision and have the ability to sit and do a project for 1-2 hours without being disruptive.

title: Carla Kaplan at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Carla Kaplan—Davis Distinguished Professor of American Literature at Northeastern University, and author of seven books, including Miss Anne in Harlem and Zora Neale Hurston—for a discussion of her new book Troublemaker: The Fierce, Unruly Life of Jessica Mitford. She will be joined in conversation by Margaret Burnham—University Distinguished Professor of Law at Northeastern University and author of By Hands Now Known: Jim Crow’s Legal Executioners. Troublemaker tells the wild and unlikely story of Jessica Mitford, fifth of the six famous Mitford Girls, a British aristocrat-turned-American Communist, famous for exposés like The American Way of Death; this biography brings her astonishing self-transformation to life with a riveting, often hilarious account of trading wealth and status for a life of radical activism. Who could predict that a British aristocrat would so energize American antifascist and civil rights struggles that Time magazine would crown her “Queen of the Muckrakers”? Jessica Mitford, always known as Decca, was brought up by an eccentric English family to marry well and reproduce her wealth and privilege, not to advocate for the rights of others. Her beautiful sisters have been subjects of books and movies dedicated to their naughty, glamorous lives. Decca ran away to America to forge a rebel’s life. As this richly researched book details, Decca broke the Mitford mold. Instead of settling for life as a professional Beauty, she fought fascism in the Spanish Civil War, became an American Communist and pioneered witty, hugely popular journalism, including her 1963 blockbuster The American Way of Death. Decca dedicated her life to social justice and proved herself an immensely effective ally, but she also injected laughter into all her political work, annoying some activists with her relentless antics but encouraging many others to find joy in the struggle. From famed baby doctor Benjamin Spock to best friend Maya Angelou, her

title: Abigail Hing Wen at The Signet Society
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Harvard alumna Abigail Hing Wen—tech leader, New York Times bestselling author of the Loveboat,Taipei series, and executive producer of the Paramount+ book-to-film adaptation Love In Taipei, now on Netflix—for a discussion of her New York Times bestselling middle-grade novel The Vale, which explores the nature of human-AI interaction, the ethics and possibilities of new technology, how children and adults can use technology responsibly, and the ways AI can change human lives. During the presentation, Abigail Hing Wen will share from her live action/animation short film prequel The Vale—Origins, starring three-time Tony Award winner Lea Salonga, along with behind-the-scenes materials and a discussion of the book. She will be joined by Grace Sun, Artist in Residence at The Signet Society, and Meredith Chamberlain, Executive Producer of The Vale—Origins. This event is perfect for parents, middle-grade readers, and anyone interested in AI. RSVP for free to this event or choose the "Book-Included" ticket to reserve a copy of The Vale and pick it up at the event. Note: Books bundled with tickets may only be picked up at the venue the night of the event, and cannot be picked up in-store beforehand. Ticket holders who purchased a book-included ticket and are unable to attend the event will be able to pick up their book at Harvard Book Store up to 30 days following the event. This offer expires after 30 days. Please note we cannot guarantee signed copies will be available to ticket holders who do not attend the event.

title: Sven Beckert at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Sven Beckert—Laird Bell Professor of History at Harvard University and author of the acclaimed book Empire of Cotton—for a discussion of his new book Capitalism: A Global History. He will be joined in conversation by Manisha Sinha—the Draper Chair in American History at the University of Connecticut and Past President of the Society for Historians of the Early American Republic. A landmark event years in the making, a brilliant global narrative that unravels the defining story of the past thousand years of human history No other phenomenon has shaped human history as decisively as capitalism. It structures how we live and work, how we think about ourselves and others, how we organize our politics. Sven Beckert, author of the Bancroft Prize–winning Empire of Cotton, places the story of capitalism within the largest conceivable geographical and historical framework, tracing its history during the past millennium and across the world. An epic achievement, his book takes us into merchant businesses in Aden and car factories in Turin, onto the terrifyingly violent sugar plantations in Barbados, and within the world of women workers in textile factories in today’s Cambodia. Capitalism, argues Beckert, was born global. Emerging from trading communities across Asia, Africa, and Europe, capitalism’s radical recasting of economic life rooted itself only gradually. But then it burst onto the world scene, as a powerful alliance between European states and merchants propelled them, and their economic logic, across the oceans. This, Beckert shows, was modern capitalism’s big bang, and one of its epicenters was the slave labor camps of the Caribbean. This system, with its hierarchies that haunt us still, provided the liftoff for the radical transformations of the Industrial Revolution. Fueled by vast productivity increases along with coal and oil, capitalism pulled down old ways of life to crown itself the defining force of the modern world. This epic d

title: Felice Frankel at the Cambridge Public Library
description: Harvard Book Store, the Harvard University Division of Science, the Harvard Library, and the Cambridge Public Library welcome Felice Frankel—award-winning science photographer and research scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the department of Chemical Engineering—for a discussion of her first book for young adults, Phenomenal Moments: Revealing the Hidden Science Around Us. She will be joined in conversation by Melissa Franklin—the Mallinckrodt Professor of Physics and Director of Graduate Studies at Harvard University. RSVP for free to this event or choose the "Book-Included" ticket to reserve a copy of Phenomenal Moments and pick it up at the event. Felice Frankel will sign copies of her book after the presentation. Note: Books bundled with tickets may only be picked up at the venue the night of the event, and cannot be picked up in-store beforehand. Ticket holders who purchased a book-included ticket and are unable to attend the event will be able to pick up their book at Harvard Book Store up to 30 days following the event. This offer expires after 30 days. Please note we cannot guarantee signed copies will be available to ticket holders who do not attend the event.

title: Terence Keel at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Terence Keel—award-winning scholar, the founding director of the BioCritical Studies Lab, and a professor of human biology, society, and African American studies at the University of California, Los Angeles—for a discussion of his new book The Coroner's Silence: Death Records and the Hidden Victims of Police Violence. He will be joined in conversation by Zohra Ahmed—an associate professor of law at Boston University. For readers of His Name Is George Floyd and Under the Skin. A landmark investigation into forensic medicine that exposes the systematic concealment of state-sanctioned violence through death investigations Each year, police officers kill over 1,000 people they've sworn to protect and serve. While some cases, like George Floyd's and Sandra Bland's, capture national attention, most victims remain nameless, their stories untold. The Coroner's Silence reveals a disturbing truth about these cases: coroners and other death investigators are often complicit in obscuring the violent circumstances of in-custody deaths. Through rigorous research—including critical records analysis, public health studies, and interviews with victims' families—this book unmasks the systemic failures within forensic medicine. Terence Keel shows how incomplete autopsy reports, mishandled medical documents, and strategically lost evidence effectively shield law enforcement from accountability. The Coroner’s Silence uncovers how the current system of death investigation operates as a mechanism of institutional safeguarding. By highlighting the structural powerlessness of coroners and their disconnection from the communities most affected by police violence, Keel demonstrates how bureaucratic processes can render human suffering invisible. True accountability requires more than procedural reform. It demands a fundamental reimagining of how we investigate, document, and understand deaths at the hands of state institutions. The Coroner's Silence is a crucial in

title: Anthony M. Amore at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Anthony M. Amore—Director of Security and Chief Investigator at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, and the bestselling author of Stealing Rembrandts, The Art of the Con, and The Woman Who Stole Vermeer—for a discussion of his new book, The Rembrandt Heist: The Story of a Criminal Genius, a Stolen Masterpiece, and an Enigmatic Friendship. He will be joined in conversation by Kelly Horan—The Boston Globe’s deputy editor for the "Ideas" section in Globe Opinion and a member of the Globe’s editorial board. A true crime tale of unbelievable friendship, loyalty, criminal genius, and a staggeringly audacious plot to steal one of the world’s most valuable paintings—and return it. On April 14, 1975, Myles Connor, already a known art thief, entered the Boston Museum of Fine Arts in disguise along with a cohort. The pair went directly the Dutch Gallery and proceeded to remove Portrait of Elsbeth van Rijn from its place on the wall. After a brief scuffle with the guards—with Myles deterring his partner from shooting a bystander—the pair was gone, leaving behind no traceable evidence amidst the mayhem.

title: Winter Warehouse Sale Frequent Buyer Shopping
description: The Harvard Book Store Warehouse Sale features thousands of new books deeply discounted up to 40-80% off the list price. The sale features books across genres, hardcover and paperback, adult and children's literature. For fans of our used books department, a featured selection is available at the sale to browse as well. The Warehouse Sale also features other bookish merchandise including totes, stationary, and apparel. Are you a member of our free Frequent Buyer Program? If so, Friday, December 5 is just for you! Join us at our warehouse in Needham, between 4 PM and 7 PM for exclusive early access to the sale. On Saturday, December 6 and Sunday December 7, the warehouse sale will be open to all customers from 9am-7pm both days.

title: Janet Lewis Saidi and Alexandra Socarides at Harvard Book Store
description: In celebration of the 250th anniversary of Jane Austen's birth, Harvard Book Store welcomes Janet Lewis Saidi—creator of The Austen Connection, a public-humanities and journalism project that connects Austen’s literature to the pop-culture and current events of our world today—and Alexandra Socarides—Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs at Emerson College, where she is a Professor of Writing, Literature, and Publishing—for a discussion of Saidi's book Jane Austen: The Original Romance Novelist, a beautifully curated book that is both an inspiring biography and a celebration of literary brilliance. They will be joined in conversation by Deidre Lynch—Ernest Bernbaum Professor of English Literature at Harvard University. Take a trip back in time to the Regency-era life of Jane Austen, one of literature’s most beloved novelists, with this captivating exploration of her works and the timeless themes of romance, family, and society. Pocket Portraits: Jane Austen takes you through the moments of Jane Austen’s life—some well-known and some which may be unexpected. These are the moments that shaped her six published novels, which draw deeply on themes of family, agency, philosophy, and love. From excerpts of her swoon-worthy tales like Pride and Prejudice and Emma to insight into Austen’s social commentary and why her works still leave their mark on contemporary pop culture, this book paints a vivid portrait of the complicated woman behind the quill. This beautifully curated book is both an inspiring biography and a celebration of literary brilliance. Whether you’re a longtime admirer of Austen or just beginning your literary adventure, Pocket Portraits: Jane Austen will leave you fascinated, inspired, and longing for more. Janet Lewis Saidi is the creator of The Austen Connection, a public-humanities and journalism project that connects Austen’s literature to the pop-culture and current events of our world today. The project has been featured in numerous publicat

title: “Pencils Up!” Porter Square Books Writer’s Hour
description: Hello Writing Enthusiasts!“Pencils Up!” is an informal monthly gathering for anyone interested in writing. Whether you’re a casual journaler or a poet laureate, join us for an hour of silent writing (and a few minutes of optional sharing at the end). Bring something you’re already working on or start something new (informal prompts will be provided). Pencils, pens, and actual paper are encouraged! Hosted by Amy Hanes at Porter Square Books: Cambridge Edition

title: TICKETED: Chloe Gong, author of Coldwire, at PSB: Cambridge Edition
description: Porter Square Books is thrilled to welcome Chloe Gong for the release of her latest novel Coldwire!

title: Amanda Foody and C.L. Herman, authors of A Fate So Cold, in conversation with Rory Power
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome Amanda Foody and C.L. Herman, authors of A Fate So Cold. Rory Power will join Foody and Herman in conversation.

title: Tom Piazza, author of Living in the Present with John Prine, in conversation with Steve Yarbrough
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome Tom Piazza for the release of Living in the Present with John Prine. Writer Steve Yarbrough will join Piazza in conversation.

title: Raging Women Collective featuring Lara Ehrlich, author of Bind Me Tighter Still, and Kristin Bair, author of Clementine Crane Prefers Not To
description: Porter Square Books is excited to host the Raging Women Collective with authors Lara Ehrlich, author of Bind Me Tighter Still, and Kristin Bair, author of Clementine Crane Prefers Not To, for a discussion about books that portray women’s rage in its many forms. As part of this event, a tattoo artist from Boston Tattoo Company will also be available onsite offering bookish flash tattoos!

title: YA Book Club with guest author Kendall Kulper
description: Please join us for the return of PSB's Young Adult (YA) Book Club! Meetings with be led by bookseller Kaliisha. The YA book club focuses on books from a variety of genres such as fantasy, contemporary, mystery, and science fiction that are all written for and star young adults aged 13-18 years old. This book club is open to all ages! We'll meet on the second Monday of every month at 7pm at Porter Square Books in Cambridge (1815 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02140). For the November meeting, author Kendall Kulper will join the group! Following a group discussion of Kendall's newest book A Time Traveler's History of Tomorrow, Kaliisha will moderate a conversation with Kendall about her work. Read the latest book releasing on November 4th (A Time Traveler's History of Tomorrow), or the previous two books (Murder for the Modern Girl and A Starlet's Secret to a Sensational Afterlife).

title: Cambridge Silent Reading Party
description: The Silent Reading Party comes to Cambridge! You can either BYOB (bring your own book) or buy a book here! We’ll be sitting and reading quietly for an hour, followed by some discussion about what we read. Or not, if you don’t feel like talking!

title: Felice Frankel, author of Phenomenal Moments
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome Felice Frankel for her book Phenomenal Moments.

title: Lacey N. Dunham, author of The Belles, and Laura Venita Green, author of Sister Creatures
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome Lacey N. Dunham and Laura Venita Green for their debut novels The Belles and Sister Creatures.

title: Matt Donovan, author of The Dug-Up Gun Museum; Nathan McClain, author of Previously Owned; and Iain Haley Pollock, author of All the Possible Bodies
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome poets Matt Donovan (The Dug-Up Gun Museum), Nathan McClain (Previously Owned), and Iain Haley Pollock (All the Possible Bodies) for a reading of poems from their recent books.

title: Sold Out: Your Own Private Bookstore 11_14_25
description: Take a friend on a book buying binge. Have a party. Enjoy the quiet of a bookstore all to yourself. (Well, all to yourself plus a few great booksellers.) Reserve Porter Square Books after it closes to the general public from 7PM-8PM on November 14 for a group of 5-10 people. The $50 reservation fee can be applied to a purchase that night. After purchasing your reservation a bookseller will be in touch to confirm.

title: Book Club: Decolonize Your Reading
description: This will be a blended genre club where we read pieces of nonfiction, fiction, and poetry to learn about Black, Indigenous, Latinx, and Asian American experiences. Example of books: There is a Rio Grande in Heaven by Ruben Reyes Jr., Making of Asian America by Erika Lee, and Felon by Reginald Dwayne Betts. This group will meet on the third Saturday of every month at 11 am at Porter Square Books in Cambridge (1815 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02140). For the November meeting, the group will read Bad Indians Book Club: Reading at the Edge of a Thousand Worlds by Patty Krawec.

title: Catherine Newman, author of Wreck, in conversation with Joanna Rakoff
description: Those who RSVP'd received an email on Nov. 6 confirming their seat.

title: Heather Aimee O'Neill, author of The Irish Goodbye, in conversation with Kristin Bair
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome Heather Aimee O'Neill for the release of The Irish Goodbye. Kristin Bair will join O'Neill in conversation.

title: Canceled: Be the Change with Cass Sunstein, author of On Liberalism: In Defense of Freedom
description: PSB's November Be the Change event features Cass Sunstein, author of On Liberalism: In Defense of Freedom.

title: Esmond Harmsworth Memorial Reading
description: Porter Square Books is honored to host a reading remembering the late Esmond Harmsworth, the literary agent who represented and impacted many local Boston area writers. The following writers will each read a selection of their work: Jedediah Berry, Lisa Borders, Gary Braver, Christopher Castellani, George Harrar, Michelle Hoover, Emily Franklin, Sarah Smith, Milo Todd, and Liza Tully.

title: Your Own Private Bookstore 11_21_25
description: Take a friend on a book buying binge. Have a party. Enjoy the quiet of a bookstore all to yourself. (Well, all to yourself plus a few great booksellers.) Reserve Porter Square Books after it closes to the general public from 7PM-8PM on November 21 for a group of 5-10 people. The $50 reservation fee can be applied to a purchase that night. After purchasing your reservation a bookseller will be in touch to confirm.

title: The Bowery Presents Autoheart: The Heartlands Tour
description: 6:00 PM VIPs 7:00 PM DOORS 8:00 PM Wild Party 9:00 PM Autoheart

title: West Coast Swing Training
description: SoleMateStudios presents a weekly Training course to help improve dancers in the skills in west coast swing.

title: WYRD: Improv Comedy Night
description: Stand up comedy open mic/competition where audience members vote when to kick the comedians off stage.

title: Denise Lafer Art Exhibition Opening Reception
description: Denise Lafer is an abstract artist living in a suburb of Boston, MA. Her paintings are inspired by both nature and major life events and are often layered to incorporate acrylic, oil stick, watercolor, or pastel. Recently, she has worked with everyday materials such as teabag paper and coffee. She currently works out of a studio in her home which she shares with her husband and two children.

title: Smut Slam
description: What’s a SMUT SLAM? I’m so glad you asked! It’s a fast-paced storytelling open mic based on REAL life, REAL lust, REAL sex. Consenting Slammers sign up on the night of to tell a 5-minute dirty story, based on their real lives, and a lucky 8-10 names will be drawn at random. A panel of celebrity judges will be on hand to evaluate your stories, and bestow the top three Slammers with a sack of sexy swag from Good Vibrations Harvard Square . You will also have the opportunity to win goodies from NJOY by submitting your anonymous questions and confessions! RULES: No notes! This is storytelling. No costumes or props! This is not theatre. Only 5 minutes! (With a 1 minute grace period) The story must be real and have happened to YOU. Stories are often funny and/or epic win but we want to encourage people to consider sharing their sad, disturbing, poignant, serious, simple and/or ‘fail’ experiences too. TAKE NOTE: Smut Slam is queer-friendly, kink-friendly AND vanilla-friendly, fat-friendly, poly-friendly… Yes, we are very friendly. We welcome people with all types and amounts of sexual experiences to our space. We DO NOT welcome stories involving racism, transphobia, homophobia, sexism or any form of discrimination, fetishization or objectification. Also, CONSENT IS KEY.

title: Somerville Winter Farmers Market
description: The Center for the Arts at the Armory is proud to offer a weekly winter market with 71+ local food vendors with the best locally grown and regionally produced foods, including fresh produce, cheese, eggs, meats, fish, breads, tamales, pastries, chocolate, skincare products, and more. Every Saturday from 9:30 am – 1:30 pm November 1, 2025 – April 11, 2026 (except Nov. 29 and Dec. 27)

title: Naughty & Nice: Holiday Movie Night at Arts at the Armory
description: What’s one of the best parts about the holiday season? The movies and the nostalgia they give us. Celebrate December-time at Arts at the Armory’s historic venue this year with a special holiday movie double feature: Home Alone and Die Hard. One ticket gets you access to both movies; fresh popcorn and quintessential movie candy will be available for purchase. Doors open at 5:30pm, Home Alone will start at 6pm. Intermission will include an ugly sweater contest for the adults and a holiday PJ contest for the kids. After the winners are announced, relax back into your seats and enjoy Die Hard at 8:15pm.

title: Young Nonprofit Professionals Network Gingerbread Building Competition
description: Join YNPN Boston as we celebrate the holiday season, make new connections in the nonprofit sector, and have some fun in the process! The gingerbread competition begins at 7:30, when participants will be randomly grouped into teams of three and have 30 minutes to build a structure out of gingerbread and sweet treats. The top three teams will be awarded prizes. RSVP is required to participate. This is a FREE event for adults. Food and beverages are available for purchase from ROOTED Café. Arts at the Armory has free parking onsite and is accessible by public transportation.

title: City of Peace
description: Khoma and Khaliava leave Kyiv-Brotherhood Monastery and venture off into the Ukrainian countryside on this summer vacation gone wrong. What was supposed to be a peaceful journey quickly turns into a harrowing adventure as the two friends learn about life, themselves, and the Vii – a demon banished from Hell.

title: Swing Boot Camp – Dec 7
description: Have you ever wanted to learn to Lindy Hop but don’t have time to commit to a weekly class? This is your chance! Our next weekend “crash course” workshop is 2.5 hours, Sundays, Noon-2:20pm. Come learn from experienced teachers who are also social dancers in the Lindy Hop scene. We will cover six count basic (East Coast Swing), basic eight count (Lindy Hop), and Charleston Basic. Moves include swing out, Lindy circle, swing out from closed, and side by side Charleston. At the end of this class, you will be able to attend a social dance and dance to music. Noon – 2:30 PM$42 advanced on-line registration, $50 at the door (register here) Epic Ballroom 26 New St Cambridge, MA 02138

title: The Whozit/Whatzit All-Star Band at Epic Ballroom!
description: The Whozit/Whatzit All-Star Band at Epic Ballroom!

title: TCS presents: Ahmed Al-kadri
description: Ahmed Al-Kadri is a Yemeni-American comedian based in Los Angeles whose stand-up blends his cultural upbringing, everyday absurdities, and straight-up goofy fun. His relatable and high-energy style has taken him around the world—from America to Asia and everywhere in between. You may have seen him on the series David Diamondhands, OFTV, or in his YouTube comedy special Special Not Special. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: Jimmy Tingle: Humor & Hope For Humanity
description: CLICK THIS TICKET LINK:Former commentator for 60 Minutes II and three-time "Best of Boston" winner comedian Jimmy Tingle returns to the theatrical stage in 2025 with the latest version of his solo show: Jimmy Tingle: Humor and Hope for Humanity. In Humor and Hope for Humanity, Jimmy will take us on a very funny and soul-searching journey from his Boston roots as an aspiring comic and street performer to network television, Harvard, a run for political office, and up to the present 2025 moment. Jimmy will speak to the challenges of the day with comedic insight, compassion and common sense during a 90-minute, laugh filled and thought-provoking tour de ’force performance. If laughter is the best medicine, then Jimmy Tingle is the Surgeon General of American humor. Clean, funny and hopeful, Jimmy will make you laugh, think, and feel better. Just what the doctor ordered to round out 2025. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: NYE Comedy Showcase & After Party
description: Ring in the New Year with unstoppable laughter at The Comedy Studio! It's the perfect way to kick off a brand-new year! This high-energy showcase brings together some of the sharpest stand-up talent from Boston and beyond for a night packed with bold punchlines, unforgettable stories, and crowd-roaring fun. Expect a fast-paced lineup of seasoned pros and rising stars, each delivering their very best sets to keep the good vibes rolling right into midnight. Whether you’re out with friends, on a date night, or looking for an upbeat way to celebrate solo, this show guarantees a warm, hilarious, and electric atmosphere that captures everything we love about Boston comedy. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

You’ll marvel at extraordinary talents you’d expect to find in Vegas, not anywhere near here! Many seats are within an arm’s reach of these death-defying performers, but reach for them, or you could end up with an acrobat in your Scorpion bowl! Put on by globe trotting performers Alex Feldman   Colin Campbell. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us!
